DataElement.preferredName: Uterine Adenosarcoma American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Stage group determined from information on the tumor (T), regional node (N) and metastases (M) and by grouping cases with similar prognosis for uterine adenosarcoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The Corpus uteri, or body of uterus, is the part of the uterus above the isthmus, comprising about two thirds of the non-pregnant organ._A low grade malignant neoplasm characterized by the presence of a benign epithelial component (tubular and cleft-like glands) and a low grade sarcomatous component that contains varying amounts of fibrous and smooth muscle tissues. In a minority of cases, the sarcomatous component contains heterologous elements including striated muscle, cartilage, and fat. It occurs in the uterine corpus, ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, and vagina. It may recur and in a minority of cases may metastasize to distant anatomic sites._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The Corpus uteri, or body of uterus, is the part of the uterus above the isthmus, comprising about two thirds of the non-pregnant organ.:A low grade malignant neoplasm characterized by the presence of a benign epithelial component (tubular and cleft-like glands) and a low grade sarcomatous component that contains varying amounts of fibrous and smooth muscle tissues. In a minority of cases, the sarcomatous component contains heterologous elements including striated muscle, cartilage, and fat. It occurs in the uterine corpus, ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, and vagina. It may recur and in a minority of cases may metastasize to distant anatomic sites.

Concepts.definition: The Corpus uteri, or body of uterus, is the part of the uterus above the isthmus, comprising about two thirds of the non-pregnant organ.

A low grade malignant neoplasm characterized by the presence of a benign epithelial component (tubular and cleft-like glands) and a low grade sarcomatous component that contains varying amounts of fibrous and smooth muscle tissues. In a minority of cases, the sarcomatous component contains heterologous elements including striated muscle, cartilage, and fat. It occurs in the uterine corpus, ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, and vagina. It may recur and in a minority of cases may metastasize to distant anatomic sites.

Property.preferredDefinition: Stage Grouping; an assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage. (caDSR)

Concepts.definition: An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Uterine Adenosarcoma American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A malignant mesenchymal tumor arising from the wall of the uterine corpus (uterine body).  The most representative examples are leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma. -- 2004_A low grade malignant neoplasm characterized by the presence of a benign epithelial component (tubular and cleft-like glands) and a low grade sarcomatous component that contains varying amounts of fibrous and smooth muscle tissues. In a minority of cases, the sarcomatous component contains heterologous elements including striated muscle, cartilage, and fat. It occurs in the uterine corpus, ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, and vagina. It may recur and in a minority of cases may metastasize to distant anatomic sites._A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage I includes: T1, N0, M0.  T1: Tumor limited to the uterus.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage I Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage I includes: T1, N0, M0.  T1: Tumor limited to the uterus.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IA includes: T1a, N0, M0.  T1a: For leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma: tumor 5 cm or less in greatest dimension.  For adenosarcoma: tumor limited to endometrium/endocervix.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IA Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IA includes: T1a, N0, M0.  T1a: For leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma: tumor 5 cm or less in greatest dimension.  For adenosarcoma: tumor limited to endometrium/endocervix.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IB includes: T1b, N0, M0.  T1b: For leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma: tumor more than 5 cm in greatest dimension.  For adenosarcoma: tumor invades to less than half of the myometrium.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IB Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IB includes: T1b, N0, M0.  T1b: For leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma: tumor more than 5 cm in greatest dimension.  For adenosarcoma: tumor invades to less than half of the myometrium.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IC includes: T1c, N0, M0.  T1c: For adenosarcoma: tumor invades more than half of the myometrium.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  Stage IC does not apply for leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IC Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IC includes: T1c, N0, M0.  T1c: For adenosarcoma: tumor invades more than half of the myometrium.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  Stage IC does not apply for leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma.  (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0.  T2: Tumor extends beyond the uterus, within the pelvis.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage II Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0.  T2: Tumor extends beyond the uterus, within the pelvis.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIIA includes: T3a, N0, M0.  T3a: Tumor infiltrates abdominal tissues, one side. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIIA Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIIA includes: T3a, N0, M0.  T3a: Tumor infiltrates abdominal tissues, one side. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIIB includes: T3b, N0, M0. T3b: Tumor infiltrates abdominal tissues, more than one side.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIIB Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIIB includes: T3b, N0, M0. T3b: Tumor infiltrates abdominal tissues, more than one side.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIIC includes: T1-T3, N1, M0.  T1: Tumor limited to the uterus. T2: Tumor extends beyond the uterus, within the pelvis.  T3: Tumor infiltrates abdominal tissues.  N1: Regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIIC Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIIC includes: T1-T3, N1, M0.  T1: Tumor limited to the uterus. T2: Tumor extends beyond the uterus, within the pelvis.  T3: Tumor infiltrates abdominal tissues.  N1: Regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVA includes: T4, Any N, M0. T4: Tumor involves bladder or rectum.  M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVA Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVA includes: T4, Any N, M0. T4: Tumor involves bladder or rectum.  M0: No distant metastasis.  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IVB includes: Any T, Any N, M1.  M1: Distal metastasis (excluding adnexa, pelvic and abdominal tissues).  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IVB Uterine Sarcoma AJCC v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IVB includes: Any T, Any N, M1.  M1: Distal metastasis (excluding adnexa, pelvic and abdominal tissues).  This staging applies to leiomyosarcoma, endometrial stromal sarcoma, and adenosarcoma. (AJCC 7th ed.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding indicating that the extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

Concepts.definition: The extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Uterine Corpus Sarcoma Adenosarcoma American Joint Committee on Cancer Stage Grouping Stage
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A malignant mesenchymal tumor arising from the wall of the uterine corpus (uterine body).  The most representative examples are leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma. -- 2004:A low grade malignant neoplasm characterized by the presence of a benign epithelial component (tubular and cleft-like glands) and a low grade sarcomatous component that contains varying amounts of fibrous and smooth muscle tissues. In a minority of cases, the sarcomatous component contains heterologous elements including striated muscle, cartilage, and fat. It occurs in the uterine corpus, ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, and vagina. It may recur and in a minority of cases may metastasize to distant anatomic sites.:A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A malignant mesenchymal neoplasm arising from the wall of the uterine corpus (uterine body).  The most representative examples are leiomyosarcoma and endometrial stromal sarcoma.

A low grade malignant neoplasm characterized by the presence of a benign epithelial component (tubular and cleft-like glands) and a low grade sarcomatous component that contains varying amounts of fibrous and smooth muscle tissues. In a minority of cases, the sarcomatous component contains heterologous elements including striated muscle, cartilage, and fat. It occurs in the uterine corpus, ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, and vagina. It may recur and in a minority of cases may metastasize to distant anatomic sites.
A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.
An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
